Notes on Minimax Rate of the Gaussian Location Model with Bounded Convex Constraints

This is a (detailed) summary of the proof techniques used by Matey Neykov in his recent paper.

Published

12 July 2022

In Spring 2022, I took the course, Information Theoretic Methods in Statistics taught by Professor Jonathan Niles Weed to learn the techniques in the source and channel coding problems of Information Theory that can also be applied to Machine Learning and Statistics. As a part of the course project, I wrote this summary of On the minimax rate of the Gaussian sequence model under bounded convex constraints by Matey Neykov.

Let’s begin by formally defining the problem.

We are given nnn observations from a Gaussian Sequence Model denoted by Yi=μi+ξiY_i = \mu_i + \xi_iYi​=μi​+ξi​, where ξi\xi_iξi​ are independent and ξi∼N(0,σ2)\xi_i \sim \mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^2)ξi​∼N(0,σ2). Suppose the vector μ\muμ belongs to a bounded convex set, KKK. We want to obtain the minimax rate of this problem under ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​ loss, i.e., we want a matching upper and lower bound of inf⁡ν^(sup⁡μ∈KE∥ν^(Y)−μ∥22),\boxed{\inf_{\hat{\nu}}\left(\sup_{\mu \in K}\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{\nu}(Y)-\mu\rVert_2^2\right)},ν^inf​(μ∈Ksup​E∥ν^(Y)−μ∥22​)​, where ν^\hat{\nu}ν^ is the set of all estimators of the data.

Pre requisites

There are two important concepts which I assume familiarity with. The first is packing of a set in a metric space, for which the Chapter 5 of (Wainwright, 2019) is a good resource. The second is measurability of a function, which is used in the subsection Measurability to prove the validity of the proposed estimator and can be skipped if the reader is not familiar with measure theory.

The paper’s main contribution is in showing that the minimax rate is (ε∗)2∧diam(K)2(\varepsilon^*)^2 \wedge \text{diam}(K)^2(ε∗)2∧diam(K)2, where ε∗\varepsilon^*ε∗ is a parameter based on the local entropy of KKK, which is defined as follows.

Local entropy, denoted Mloc(ε)M^{loc}(\varepsilon)Mloc(ε), is the largest cardinality of an εc\tfrac{\varepsilon}{c}cε​ - packing set (c>0c > 0c>0) of the intersection of KKK with B(θ,ε)B(\theta,\varepsilon)B(θ,ε), where θ∈K\theta \in Kθ∈K. \begin{align*} \boxed{M^{loc}(\varepsilon) := \sup_{\theta \in K} M \left(\frac{\varepsilon}{c}, B(\theta, \varepsilon) \cap K \right)}, \end{align*} where M(δ,T)M(\delta,\mathbb{T})M(δ,T) is the δ\deltaδ packing number of a set T\mathbb{T}T.

List of Sections

In Section 1 we will see that it is straightforward to get a lower bound of the minimax rate using Fano’s inequality if the local entropy is sufficiently large.

Section 2 contains the main results involving the minimax upper bound where we will learn about the algorithm to obtain the estimator ν∗\nu^*ν∗. Then, we check the validity of this estimator by showing that ν∗\nu^*ν∗ is a measurable function.

In the subsequent sections, we will see that if the ν∗\nu^*ν∗ is selected from the Algorithm defined in Section 222, then with high probability, ν∗(Y)\nu^*(Y)ν∗(Y) is close to μ\muμ. This is done by showing that the binary hypothesis testing problem that picks the estimator based on its distance to YYY has low type 111 and 222 errors. Finally, we show an upper bound on E∥ν∗(Y)−μ∥22\mathbb{E}\lVert\nu^* (Y) - \mu\rVert_2^2E∥ν∗(Y)−μ∥22​. This result, along with geometric properties of local entropy gives the minimax rate.

1. Lower Bound

(1) The minimax risk has a lower bound of ε28c2\frac{\varepsilon^2}{8c^2}8c2ε2​ for any ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0 such that log⁡Mloc(ε)>4(ε22σ2∨log⁡2)\log M^{loc} (\varepsilon) > 4 (\frac{\varepsilon^2}{2\sigma^2} \vee \log 2)logMloc(ε)>4(2σ2ε2​∨log2).
Let μ1,μ2,…,μm\mu^1,\mu^2, \ldots, \mu^mμ1,μ2,…,μm be ε\varepsilonε seperated points in KKK. Suppose JJJ is uniformly distributed over the index set [m][m][m] and the conditional distribution of YYY given J=jJ = jJ=j is equal to the distribution of μj+ξ\mu_j + \xiμj​+ξ where ξ∼N(0,Iσ2)\xi \sim \mathcal{N}(0,I \sigma^2)ξ∼N(0,Iσ2). \newline \newline To apply Fano's inequality, we need an upper bound on the mutual information between YYY and JJJ. Note that I(Y;J)≤1m∑j=1mDKL(Pμj∣∣Pν)I(Y;J)\le \frac{1}{m} \sum_{j=1}^m D_{KL}(\mathbb{P}_{\mu^j}||\mathbb{P}_\nu)I(Y;J)≤m1​∑j=1m​DKL​(Pμj​∣∣Pν​) for any ν∈Rn\nu \in \R^nν∈Rn where Px\mathbb{P}_xPx​ the the Gaussian measure centered at xxx with variance σ2I\sigma^2Iσ2I. Therefore, for any pair (μj,ν)(\mu^j,\nu)(μj,ν), DKL(Pμj∣∣Pν)=∥μj−ν∥222σ2.D_{KL}(\mathbb{P}_{\mu^j}||\mathbb{P}_{\nu}) = \frac{\lVert\mu^j - \nu\rVert_2^2}{2\sigma^2}.DKL​(Pμj​∣∣Pν​)=2σ2∥μj−ν∥22​​. And thus, \begin{align*} I(Y;J) \le \frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^m \frac{\lVert\mu^j - \nu\rVert_2^2}{2\sigma^2} &\le \max_{j} \frac{\lVert\mu^j - \nu\rVert_2^2}{2\sigma^2}. \end{align*} Now, the maximum distance between μj\mu^jμj and ν\nuν is ε\varepsilonε and so applying Fano's inequality we get the following: \begin{align*} \inf_{\hat{\nu}}\sup_{\mu}\mathbb{E}\lVert\hat{\nu}(Y) - \mu\rVert_2^2 &\ge \frac{\varepsilon^2}{4c^2}\left(1-\frac{\frac{\varepsilon^2}{2\sigma^2} + \log 2}{\log M^{loc}(\varepsilon)}\right). \end{align*} To conclude, if log⁡Mloc(ε)>2(ε22σ2+log⁡2)\log M^{loc}(\varepsilon) > 2 (\frac{\varepsilon^2}{2\sigma^2} + \log 2)logMloc(ε)>2(2σ2ε2​+log2), we get a lower bound of ε24c2⋅(1−12)=ε28c2\frac{\varepsilon^2}{4c^2}\cdot (1-\frac{1}{2}) = \boxed{\frac{\varepsilon^2}{8c^2}}4c2ε2​⋅(1−21​)=8c2ε2​​.

In the next sections, we will see how the condition of lemma 1 will be satisfied.

2. Upper Bound

The Algorithm to get the estimator

Suppose ddd is the diameter of the set KKK. The estimator is returned at the end of the following process:

  • Begin with ν∗∈K\nu^* \in Kν∗∈K, 2(C+1)=c2(C+1) = c2(C+1)=c
  • Repeat for all k∈Nk \in \Nk∈N
    • Construct a d2k(C+1)\frac{d}{2^{k}(C+1)}2k(C+1)d​maximal packing, MkM_kMk​, of the set K∩B(ν∗,d2k−1)K \cap B(\nu^*, \frac{d}{2^{k-1}})K∩B(ν∗,2k−1d​)
    • Find the closest point to YYY in MkM_kMk​ and reassign it as ν∗\nu^*ν∗

This algorithm picks a random point ν∗∈K\nu^* \in Kν∗∈K, constructs a d2\frac{d}{2}2d​ packing of the intersection of KKK with a ball of radius ddd, which in the beginning is the set KKK. Then, it finds the point in this packing closest to YYY in the ∥.∥2\lVert . \rVert_2∥.∥2​.

Now the entire process is repeated with the ball centered at the previous closest point with the radius of the ball and packing halved.

There are a couple of points to note in this algorithm.

First, such a process is not achievable in practice because k∈Nk \in \mathbb{N}k∈N.

Second, any point Y∈KY \in KY∈K can be reached through this algorithm. This is because if the point in KKK is in any one level of the packings then we are done. Otherwise, YYY can be reached in the limit since the union of all such packings, is a countably dense subset of KKK. It is countable because it is the union of countable finite sets. And dense because for any δ>0\delta > 0δ>0, and Y∈KY \in KY∈K, the set B(Y,δ)B(Y, \delta)B(Y,δ) will contain at least one point that belongs to a 2δ2\delta2δ packing.

Measurability

We argue ν∗\nu^*ν∗ is a valid statistic by showing that it is a measurable function of the data. Let Υk:Rn→Rn\Upsilon_k: \R^n \to \R^nΥk​:Rn→Rn return the estimator at the level kkk. This means that Υk\Upsilon_kΥk​ maps a point in Mk−1M_{k-1}Mk−1​ (that was closest to YYY at level k−1k-1k−1) to a point in MkM_kMk​ that is closest to YYY.

(2) The function ν∗:Rn→Rn\nu^*:\R^n \to \R^nν∗:Rn→Rn is measurable in the Borel σ\sigmaσ algebra.
First, consider the event that Υk(y)\Upsilon_k(y)Υk​(y) belongs to a packing set MMM. For any point m∈Mm \in Mm∈M, the set {y:Υk(y)=m}\{y: \Upsilon_k(y) = m \}{y:Υk​(y)=m} is the set of all yyy such that Υk(y)∈M\Upsilon_k(y) \in MΥk​(y)∈M and yyy belongs to a polytope (given by the Voronoi tesselation by MMM). Since KKK is convex, this is the set of all yyy which belong to a convex polytope. A convex polytope is a countable combination of of closed sets, making the inverse image of a singleton, Υk−1({m})\Upsilon_k^{-1}(\{m\})Υk−1​({m}) a Borel set. Now, since MkM_kMk​ is a packing, it is a finite set. This implies that Υk\Upsilon_kΥk​ is a discrete function and the σ\sigmaσ algebra is generated from singleton. So we can say that Υk\Upsilon_kΥk​ is a measurable function. Note that the sequence {Υk}\{\Upsilon_k\}{Υk​} is convergent because it is Cauchy since for any k1<k2k_1< k_2k1​<k2​, \begin{align*} \lVert\Upsilon_{k_1} - \Upsilon_{k_2}\rVert_2 &= \lVert\Upsilon_{k_1} - \Upsilon_{k_1 + 1} + \Upsilon_{k_1+1} + \ldots \Upsilon_{k_2}\rVert_2.\\ &\le \sum_{i=k_1}^{k_2-1}\lVert\Upsilon_{i} - \Upsilon_{i+1}\rVert_2\\ &\le \sum_{i=k_1}^{k_2 -1 }\frac{d}{2^{i-1}} \le \frac{d}{2^{k_1 - 1}} \end{align*} The inequalities above are a consequence of Triangle Inequality. \newline Note that our estimator is achieved in the limit i.e. \begin{align*} \nu^* &= \lim_{k \to \infty }\Upsilon_k\\ &= \lim \sup_{k \to \infty} \Upsilon_k. \end{align*} So, to see that ν∗\nu^*ν∗ is measurable, it suffices to show that for any closed box BBB, (ν∗)−1(B)(\nu^*)^{-1}(B)(ν∗)−1(B) is a Borel set. \newline If BjLB_j^LBjL​ and BjUB_j^UBjU​ are the upper and lower bounds of BBB for the jjjth co-ordinate, then our problem reduces to proving that ⋂j=1n{y:lim⁡sup⁡k→∞Υkj(y)∈[BjL,BjU]}\boxed{\bigcap_{j=1}^n\{y: \lim \sup_{k \to \infty} \Upsilon_k^j (y) \in [B_j^L, B_j^U]\}}j=1⋂n​{y:limk→∞sup​Υkj​(y)∈[BjL​,BjU​]}​ is Borel. \newline Each set in the above intersection can be written as following. \begin{align*} \{y: \lim \sup_{k \to \infty} \Upsilon_k^j (y) \in [B_j^L, B_j^U]\} &= \{y : \lim \sup_{k \to \infty} \Upsilon_k^j(y) \ge B_j^L\} \cap \{y:\lim \sup_{k \to \infty} \Upsilon_k^j(y) \le B_j^U\} \\ &:= P \cap Q \end{align*} From the definition of lim⁡sup⁡\lim \suplimsup of sets, QQQ is ⋂k=1∞⋃i=k∞{y:Υij(y)≥BjL}\bigcap_{k=1}^\infty \bigcup_{i=k}^\infty\{y:\Upsilon_i^j(y) \ge B_j^L\}⋂k=1∞​⋃i=k∞​{y:Υij​(y)≥BjL​}, which is measurable since Υi\Upsilon_iΥi​ is measurable and this is a countable combination of measurable sets. \newline PPP can be written as ⋂l=1∞{y:Υkj(y)<BjL+1l}\bigcap_{l=1}^\infty \{y:\Upsilon_k^j(y) < B_j^L + \frac{1}{l}\}⋂l=1∞​{y:Υkj​(y)<BjL​+l1​}. From a property of lim⁡sup⁡\lim \suplimsup, if a>lim⁡sup⁡Υka > \lim \sup \Upsilon_ka>limsupΥk​, then there exists an N∈NN \in \mathbb{N}N∈N such that for all n≥Nn \ge Nn≥N Υk<a\Upsilon_k < aΥk​<a. This translates in set notation as ⋂l=1∞⋃k=1∞⋂i=k∞{y:Υij(y)<BjU}\bigcap_{l=1}^\infty \bigcup_{k=1}^\infty \bigcap_{i=k}^\infty\{y: \Upsilon_i^j(y) < B_j^U\}⋂l=1∞​⋃k=1∞​⋂i=k∞​{y:Υij​(y)<BjU​}, which is again measurable.

Mapping to the Binary Hypothesis Testing Problem

We know from the previous section that $\nu^*$ is close to $Y$. To understand whether it is close to $\mu$, we pose this as a binary hypothesis testing problem and show that in a $\delta$ packing, the type $1$ and $2$ errors are small.

(3) Consider the hypothesis H0:μ=ν1H_0: \mu = \nu_1H0​:μ=ν1​ and H1:μ=ν2H_1: \mu= \nu_2H1​:μ=ν2​ for ∥ν1−ν2∥2≥Cδ\lVert \nu_1 - \nu_2 \rVert_2 \ge C\delta∥ν1​−ν2​∥2​≥Cδ, where C>2C> 2C>2. Then the test, ψ(Y)=1∥Y−ν1∥2>∥Y−ν2∥2\psi(Y) = \mathbb{1}_{\lVert Y - \nu_1\rVert_2 > \lVert Y - \nu_2 \rVert_2}ψ(Y)=1∥Y−ν1​∥2​>∥Y−ν2​∥2​​ satisfies the following: \begin{align*} \min \left(\sup_{\mu:\lVert\mu - \nu_1 \rVert_2 \le \delta} \mathbb{P}_\mu(\psi=1) ,\sup_{\mu:\lVert \mu -\nu_2 \rVert_2 \le \delta}\mathbb{P}_\mu(\psi=0)\right)\le \exp \left(- (C-2 ) \frac{\delta^2}{8\sigma^2}\right). \end{align*}
We demonstrate the result for Type 111 error, and the same argument holds for Type 222. \newline The Type 111 error implies that ∥μ−ν1∥2≤δ\lVert \mu - \nu_1 \rVert_2 \le \delta∥μ−ν1​∥2​≤δ and ψ(Y)=1\psi(Y) = 1ψ(Y)=1 which holds if ∥Y−ν1∥22−∥Y−ν2∥22≥0,\lVert Y - \nu_1\rVert_2 ^2 - \lVert Y - \nu_2\rVert_2 ^2 \ge 0,∥Y−ν1​∥22​−∥Y−ν2​∥22​≥0, i.e. YYY is closer to ν2\nu_2ν2​. \newline Next, note that the random variable Z:=∥Y−ν1∥22−∥Y−ν2∥22Z:=\lVert Y - \nu_1\rVert_2^2 - \lVert Y - \nu_2\rVert_2^2Z:=∥Y−ν1​∥22​−∥Y−ν2​∥22​ is normally distributed and the error is bounded from the tail probability of a subgaussian random variable which can be written as ∥ν1∥22+∥ν2∥22+2(μ+ξ)T(ν2−ν1)\lVert \nu_1\rVert_2^2 + \lVert\nu_2\rVert_2^2 + 2(\mu + \xi)^T(\nu_2 - \nu_1)∥ν1​∥22​+∥ν2​∥22​+2(μ+ξ)T(ν2​−ν1​). Letting μ=ν1+η\mu = \nu_1 + \etaμ=ν1​+η such that ∥η∥2≤δ\lVert\eta\rVert_2\le \delta∥η∥2​≤δ, gives us Z=∥ν1∥22+∥ν2∥22+2(ν1+η+ξ)T(ν2−ν1),Z = \lVert\nu_1\rVert_2^2 + \lVert\nu_2\rVert_2^2 + 2(\nu_1 + \eta + \xi)^T(\nu_2 - \nu_1),Z=∥ν1​∥22​+∥ν2​∥22​+2(ν1​+η+ξ)T(ν2​−ν1​), which is equal to −∥ν1−ν2∥22+2(η+ξ)T(ν2−ν1)-\lVert\nu_1 - \nu_2\rVert_2^2 + 2(\eta+\xi)^T(\nu_2 - \nu_1)−∥ν1​−ν2​∥22​+2(η+ξ)T(ν2​−ν1​). \newline Now, note that ηT(ν2−ν1)≤∥η∥2∥ν2−ν1∥2≤δ∥ν2−ν1∥2.\eta^T(\nu_2 - \nu_1)\le \lVert\eta\rVert_2 \lVert\nu_2 - \nu_1\rVert_2 \le \delta \lVert \nu_2 - \nu_1\rVert_2.ηT(ν2​−ν1​)≤∥η∥2​∥ν2​−ν1​∥2​≤δ∥ν2​−ν1​∥2​. From the assumption of packing, δ≤∥ν1−ν2∥2/C\delta \le \lVert\nu_1 - \nu_2\rVert_2/Cδ≤∥ν1​−ν2​∥2​/C, giving that ηT(ν2−ν1)≤∥ν1−ν2∥22C.\eta^T(\nu_2 - \nu_1) \le \frac{\lVert\nu_1 - \nu_2\rVert_2^2}{C}.ηT(ν2​−ν1​)≤C∥ν1​−ν2​∥22​​. Since ξ∼N(0,σ2)\xi \sim \N(0, \sigma^2)ξ∼N(0,σ2), from the stability of Gaussians, Z∼N(θ,4σ2∥ν1−ν2∥22)Z \sim \N(\theta, 4\sigma^2 \lVert\nu_1 - \nu_2\rVert_2^2)Z∼N(θ,4σ2∥ν1​−ν2​∥22​), where θ≤(2/C−1)∥ν1−ν2∥22\theta \le (2/C - 1)\lVert\nu_1 - \nu_2\rVert_2^2θ≤(2/C−1)∥ν1​−ν2​∥22​. \newline Finally, applying the tail probability bound on Gaussians concludes the proof.

We now show that the above result extends to all points in MMM.

(4) Let i∗=arg⁡min⁡i∈M∥Y−νi∥2i^* = \arg \min_{i\in M}\lVert Y - \nu_i\rVert_2i∗=argmini∈M​∥Y−νi​∥2​. Then with probability at least 1−∣M∣⋅exp⁡(−(C−2)2δ28σ2)1-\lvert M\rvert \cdot \exp\left(- \frac{(C-2)^2\delta^2}{8\sigma^2}\right)1−∣M∣⋅exp(−8σ2(C−2)2δ2​), ∥νi∗−μ∥2≤(C+1)δ.\lVert\nu_{i^*} - \mu\rVert_2\le (C+1)\delta.∥νi∗​−μ∥2​≤(C+1)δ.
The ingredients of this proof are triangle inequality, characterising the event as the type 111 error of the test in lemma 3 and a union bound. \newline First, the author defines an intermediate random variable, TiT_iTi​ which is the maximum distance between νi\nu_iνi​ and another point, νj\nu_jνj​ in the packing set such that νj\nu_jνj​ is closer to YYY than νi\nu_iνi​, i.e. max⁡j∥νi−νj∥2\max_{j}\lVert \nu_i - \nu_j \rVert_2maxj​∥νi​−νj​∥2​ such that ∥Y−νi∥2≥∥Y−νj∥2\lVert Y - \nu_i\rVert_2 \ge \lVert Y - \nu_j\rVert_2∥Y−νi​∥2​≥∥Y−νj​∥2​ and ∥νi−νj∥2≥Cδ\lVert \nu_i - \nu_j\rVert_2\ge C\delta∥νi​−νj​∥2​≥Cδ. If no such jjj exists then Ti=0T_i = 0Ti​=0. \newline Analysing the probability in the statement, we can see that \begin{align*} \mathbb{P}\{\lVert \nu_{i^*} - \mu \rVert_2\ge(C+1)\delta \} &\le \mathbb{P}\{\lVert\nu_i^* - \nu_i\rVert_2 + \lVert \nu_i - \mu\rVert_2 \ge (C+1)\delta\}. \end{align*} Since MMM is the δ\deltaδ packing, it is also a δ\deltaδ covering and thus ∥μ−νi∥2≤δ\lVert\mu - \nu_i \rVert_2\le \delta∥μ−νi​∥2​≤δ for some iii. So the above probability is equal to P{∥νi∗−νi∥2+δ≥Cδ+δ}=P{i∗∈{j:∥νi−νj∥2≥Cδ}}\mathbb{P}\{ \lVert\nu_i^* - \nu_i \rVert_2 + \delta \ge C\delta + \delta\} = \mathbb{P}\{i^* \in \{j:\lVert\nu_i - \nu_j\rVert_2\ge C\delta\}\}P{∥νi∗​−νi​∥2​+δ≥Cδ+δ}=P{i∗∈{j:∥νi​−νj​∥2​≥Cδ}}. Now if i∗i^*i∗ belongs to the set of all νj\nu_jνj​ which are CδC\deltaCδ away from νi\nu_iνi​, then this means that Ti≥Cδ>0T_i \ge C\delta > 0Ti​≥Cδ>0 since we already know that i∗i^*i∗ is closer to YYY. The probability that Ti>0T_i > 0Ti​>0 is the same as the probability that there exists a jjj which satisfies the condition of TiT_iTi​, which is the probability of type 111 error for each jjj. By a union bound over all j∈Mj \in Mj∈M and lemma 4 we get the desired result.

Before proving the rate, let us briefly state a result that will be heavily used in next two theorems.

(5) The function ε→Mloc(ε)\varepsilon \to M^{loc}(\varepsilon)ε→Mloc(ε) is monotone non increasing.
The above can be proved by showing that for any ε′<ε\varepsilon'<\varepsilonε′<ε, K∩B(θ,ε′)⊃K∩B(θ,ε)K \cap B(\theta, \varepsilon') \supset K \cap B(\theta, \varepsilon)K∩B(θ,ε′)⊃K∩B(θ,ε). This involves showing that an affine transformation of K∩B(θ,ε′)K \cap B(\theta, \varepsilon')K∩B(θ,ε′) gives K∩B(θ,ε)K\cap B(\theta, \varepsilon)K∩B(θ,ε), which by convexity is in the set with ε′\varepsilon'ε′.

The next theorem is important to get the (ε∗)2(\varepsilon^*)^2(ε∗)2 part of the rate.

(6) If ν∗\nu^*ν∗ is returned by the previously defined Algorithm, then E∥μ−ν∗(Y)∥22≤Cˉ(ε∗)2,\boxed{\mathbb{E}\lVert\mu - \nu^*(Y)\rVert_2^2 \le \bar{C}(\varepsilon^*)^2},E∥μ−ν∗(Y)∥22​≤Cˉ(ε∗)2​, where ε∗\varepsilon^*ε∗ is the maximal J∈NJ\in \mathbb{N}J∈N such that εJ=d2J−2⋅c/2−3c\varepsilon_J = \frac{d}{2^{J-2}}\cdot \frac{c/2-3}{c}εJ​=2J−2d​⋅cc/2−3​ and εJ2σ2>16log⁡Mloc(εJcc/2−3)∨16log⁡2\frac{\varepsilon_J^2}{\sigma^2}> 16 \log M^{loc}\left(\frac{\varepsilon_J c}{c/2 - 3}\right) \vee 16\log 2σ2εJ2​​>16logMloc(c/2−3εJ​c​)∨16log2 or ε1\varepsilon_1ε1​, if no such JJJ exists.
Throughout the proof, we attempt to simplify the numerous variables used to defined ε∗\varepsilon^*ε∗. To apply the results from lemma 4 , it is important to see that MMM is the packing set for all levels up till JJJ. So, applying the lemma and adjusting the constant ccc in MlocM^{loc}Mloc gives us the following: \begin{align*} \mathbb{P}\{\lVert\mu - \Upsilon_J\rVert_2 \ge \frac{d}{2^{J-1}}\} &\le \sum_{j=1}^{J-1} \lvert M_j \rvert \exp\left(-\frac{(C-2)^2d^2}{2^{2j}(C+1)^2 8\sigma^2}\right). \end{align*} Since ε→Mloc(ε)\varepsilon \to M^{loc}(\varepsilon)ε→Mloc(ε) is monotone decreasing from lemma 5 this probability is bounded from above by Mloc(d2J−2)∑j=1J−1exp⁡(−(C−2)2d222j(C+1)28σ2)M^{loc}(\frac{d}{2^{J-2}}) \sum_{j=1}^{J-1}\exp\left(-\frac{(C-2)^2d^2}{2^{2j}(C+1)^2 8\sigma^2}\right)Mloc(2J−2d​)∑j=1J−1​exp(−22j(C+1)28σ2(C−2)2d2​). This probability is further ≤Mloc(d2J−2)a1−a\le M^{loc}(\frac{d}{2^{J-2}})\frac{a}{1-a}≤Mloc(2J−2d​)1−aa​ for J>1J > 1J>1 where aaa is the last term of the summation, which is exp⁡(−(C−2)2d222(J−1)(C+1)28σ2)\exp\left(-\frac{(C-2)^2d^2}{2^{2(J-1)}(C+1)^2 8\sigma^2}\right)exp(−22(J−1)(C+1)28σ2(C−2)2d2​). Let εJ=d2J−1⋅C−2C+1\varepsilon_J = \frac{d}{2^{J-1}}\cdot \frac{C-2}{C+1}εJ​=2J−1d​⋅C+1C−2​. Setting c=2(C+1)c = 2(C+1)c=2(C+1) matches the definition of εJ\varepsilon_JεJ​. Now, assuming a<1/2a < 1/2a<1/2 and 2log⁡(Mloc(d2J−1))2\log(M^{loc}(\frac{d}{2^{J-1}}))2log(Mloc(2J−1d​)) to be bounded by the exponential part of aaa which is 2log⁡(Mloc(d2J−1))≤εJ28σ22\log(M^{loc}(\frac{d}{2^{J-1}})) \le \frac{\varepsilon_J^2}{8\sigma^2}2log(Mloc(2J−1d​))≤8σ2εJ2​​, we get: \begin{align*} \mathbb{P}\{\lVert\mu - \Upsilon_J\rVert_2 \ge \frac{d}{2^{J-2}}\} \le 2\exp\left(-\frac{\varepsilon_J^2}{16\sigma^2}\right) \end{align*} To show that μJ\mu_JμJ​ is not too far from ν∗\nu^*ν∗, we apply triangle inequality and the fact that the sequence {ΥJ}\{\Upsilon_J\}{ΥJ​} is Cauchy, which implies that ∥ΥJ−ν∗∥2=∥ΥJ−lim⁡J→∞ΥJ∥2≤d2J−1\lVert\Upsilon_J - \nu^*\rVert_2 = \lVert\Upsilon_J - \lim_{J \to \infty} \Upsilon_J\rVert_2 \le \frac{d}{2^{J-1}}∥ΥJ​−ν∗∥2​=∥ΥJ​−limJ→∞​ΥJ​∥2​≤2J−1d​. Therefore, we get the following result w.p ≥1−2exp⁡(−εJ216σ2)\ge 1-2 \exp(-\frac{\varepsilon_J^2}{16\sigma^2})≥1−2exp(−16σ2εJ2​​) \begin{align*} \lVert\nu^* - \mu\rVert_2 &\le \lVert\nu^* - \mu\rVert_2 + \lVert \mu - \Upsilon_J\rVert_2 \le 3\frac{d}{2^{J-1}} = 3 \varepsilon_J \frac{C+1}{C-2} \end{align*} Let J∗J^*J∗ be the maximum J>1J > 1J>1 such that the assumption on 2log⁡(Mloc(d2J−1))2 \log(M^{loc}(\frac{d}{2^{J-1}}))2log(Mloc(2J−1d​)) holds, otherwise we set J∗=1J^* = 1J∗=1, which in turn implies the condition on εJ2σ2\frac{\varepsilon_J^2}{\sigma^2}σ2εJ2​​. The author then shows that for any x≥ε∗x \ge \varepsilon^*x≥ε∗, P{∥μ−ν∗∥2≥C′x}≤C‾exp⁡(−C′′x2/σ2)1J∗>1\mathbb{P}\{\lVert\mu - \nu^*\rVert_2 \ge C' x\} \le \underline{C}\exp(-C''x^2/\sigma^2)\mathbb{1}_{J^* > 1}P{∥μ−ν∗∥2​≥C′x}≤C​exp(−C′′x2/σ2)1J∗>1​ by applying that x→C‾exp⁡(−C′′x2/σ2)x \to \underline{C}\exp(-C''x^2/\sigma^2)x→C​exp(−C′′x2/σ2) is monotone decreasing. \newline Finally, we get the upper bound on expectation by integrating the tail probability, E∥μ−ν∗∥22=∫0∞2xP{∥μ−ν∗∥2≥x}dx\mathbb{E}\lVert\mu - \nu^*\rVert_2^2 = \int_{0}^\infty 2x \mathbb{P}\{\lVert\mu - \nu^*\rVert_2\ge x\}\mathrm{d} xE∥μ−ν∗∥22​=∫0∞​2xP{∥μ−ν∗∥2​≥x}dx. From the above analysis, with high probability, ∥μ−ν∗∥2\lVert\mu - \nu^*\rVert_2∥μ−ν∗∥2​ is bounded by C′ε∗C'\varepsilon^*C′ε∗. Thus, we get the following: \begin{align*} \mathbb{E}\lVert\mu - \nu^*\rVert_2^2 &\le C_1(\varepsilon^*)^2 + \int_{C'\varepsilon^*}^\infty 2x \exp(-C''x^2/\sigma^2) \mathbb{1}_{J^* > 1} \\ &= C_1(\varepsilon^*)^2 + C_2\sigma^2\exp(-C_3(\varepsilon^*)^2/\sigma^2)\mathbb{1}_{J^* > 1} \end{align*} Since εJ∗/σ2\varepsilon_J^*/\sigma^2εJ∗​/σ2 is greater than some constant from the assumption, this gives the desired result.

3. Proof of the Minimax Rate

In the concluding section, we will show how the minimax rate of (ε∗)2∧diam(K)2(\varepsilon^*)^2 \wedge \text{diam}(K)^2(ε∗)2∧diam(K)2 is achieved.

(7) If ε∗\varepsilon^*ε∗ is now defined as sup⁡{ε:ε2σ2≤log⁡(Mloc(ε))}\sup\{\varepsilon: \frac{\varepsilon^2}{\sigma^2}\le \log(M^{loc}(\varepsilon))\}sup{ε:σ2ε2​≤log(Mloc(ε))}, then the minimax rate is (ε∗)2∧diam(K)2\boxed{(\varepsilon^*)^2 \wedge \text{diam}(K)^2}(ε∗)2∧diam(K)2​.
Consider the following two cases:
  1. (ε∗)2σ2>16log⁡2\frac{(\varepsilon^*)^2}{\sigma^2} > 16\log 2σ2(ε∗)2​>16log2: The lower and upper bounds in this case are (ε∗)2(\varepsilon^*)^2(ε∗)2.
    • Lower Bound : If ε∗\varepsilon^*ε∗ is the supremum of the above set then ε∗/4\varepsilon^*/4ε∗/4 lies in the set. Therefore, log⁡(Mloc(ε∗/4))≥(ε∗)24σ2=(ε∗)28σ2+(ε∗)28σ2≥2log⁡2+2(ε∗/4)2σ2\log(M^{loc}(\varepsilon^*/4))\ge \frac{(\varepsilon^*)^2}{4\sigma^2} = \frac{(\varepsilon^*)^2}{8\sigma^2} + \frac{(\varepsilon^*)^2}{8\sigma^2} \ge 2\log 2 + \frac{2(\varepsilon^*/4)^2}{\sigma^2}log(Mloc(ε∗/4))≥4σ2(ε∗)2​=8σ2(ε∗)2​+8σ2(ε∗)2​≥2log2+σ22(ε∗/4)2​. Thus (ε∗)2/4(\varepsilon^*)^2/4(ε∗)2/4 satisfies the sufficient condition of lemma 1 giving a lower bound of C‾(ε∗)2\underline{C}(\varepsilon^*)^2C​(ε∗)2
    • Upper Bound : Since ε∗>0\varepsilon^*> 0ε∗>0, 2ε∗2\varepsilon^*2ε∗ does not lie in the set and for any C>1C > 1C>1, C(2ε∗)2σ2≥Clog⁡(Mloc(2ε∗))\frac{C(2\varepsilon^*)^2}{\sigma^2} \ge C\log(M^{loc}(2\varepsilon^*))σ2C(2ε∗)2​≥Clog(Mloc(2ε∗)). This in turn is bounded below by Clog⁡(Mloc(2ε∗C))C\log (M^{loc}(2\varepsilon^*\sqrt{C}))Clog(Mloc(2ε∗C​)) from the monotonicity of MlocM^{loc}Mloc. Placing C=16C = 16C=16 gives that 2ε∗C2\varepsilon^*C2ε∗C satisfies the sufficient condition for theorem 6 giving an upper bound of C‾(ε∗)2\overline{C}(\varepsilon^*)^2C(ε∗)2
  2. (ε∗)2σ2≤16log⁡2\frac{(\varepsilon^*)^2}{\sigma^2} \le 16\log 2σ2(ε∗)2​≤16log2: The rate in this case is proportional to diam(K)2:=d2\text{diam}(K)^2:=d^2diam(K)2:=d2/ Again, 2ε∗2\varepsilon^*2ε∗ is not in the set and hence log⁡(Mloc(2ε∗))≤4(ε∗)2σ2\log (M^{loc}(2\varepsilon^*))\le \frac{4(\varepsilon^*)^2}{\sigma^2} log(Mloc(2ε∗))≤σ24(ε∗)2​, which from the assumption is upper bounded by 64log⁡264\log 264log2. This means that exp⁡(64log⁡2)\exp(64\log 2)exp(64log2) points are enough to pack KKK. Further note that if ccc is large enough, i.e. the packing radius is small enough, then placing ≥exp⁡(64log⁡2)\ge \exp(64 \log 2)≥exp(64log2) points at the diameter of a ball of radius 2ε∗2\varepsilon^*2ε∗ gives us a packing set. This implies that KKK lies entirely in a ball of radius 2ε∗≤64log⁡2σ2\varepsilon^*\le \sqrt{64\log 2}\sigma2ε∗≤64log2​σ. The author claims that it is not needed to take the supremum of the set, instead choosing ε\varepsilonε to be proportional to ddd should suffice. This will ensure that ε2/σ2=d2/σ2≤(4ε∗)2/σ2\varepsilon^2/\sigma^2 = d^2 /\sigma^2 \le (4\varepsilon^*)^2/\sigma^2ε2/σ2=d2/σ2≤(4ε∗)2/σ2 will be upper bounded by a constant (from the assumption). And Mloc(ε)M^{loc}(\varepsilon)Mloc(ε) can be made larger than a constant by placing θ\thetaθ at the center of the diameter of KKK constructing a packing set from equidistant points along the diameter. This method gives us matching upper and lower bounds of d2d^2d2 upto constant factors.
Combining the previous two cases gives the desired minimax rate.

4. Discussion and Open Directions

The assumption of convexity is universal and occurs in applications like isotonic regression where KKK is a convex cone and linear prediction with correlated designs where KKK is an ellipse (Guntuboyina and Sen, 2018) .

The author thus gives a minimax optimal estimator on a general problem than KKK taking a specific shape. In the remaining part of the paper, he also shows show ε∗\varepsilon^*ε∗ can be calculated for certain convex bodies like hyperrectangles and ellipses.

There are two major concepts in his proof: the boundedness of local entropy and convexity. Convexity of KKK plays an important role in showing that the local entropy is a decreasing function of ε\varepsilonε, which in turn is applied in bounding E∥ν∗−μ∥2\mathbb{E}\lVert\nu^* - \mu\rVert_2E∥ν∗−μ∥2​ from above. A question to think about is how to extend this to other constraints on KKK.

Finally, another open question is to understand if it is possible to get a computationally tractable estimator that achieves this minimax rate.

  1. Wainwright, Martin J. (2019). High-Dimensional Statistics: A Non-Asymptotic Viewpoint, Cambridge University Press , 121, Cambridge Series in Statistical and Probabilistic Mathematics
  2. Guntuboyina, Adityanand and Sen, Bodhisattva. (2018). Nonparametric shape-restricted regression, Statistical Science
